quoteFirst: On its right bank was a level flat of cellular lava or basalt. Following the course of the creek, at
quoteLast: camped at a fine lagoon a quarter of a mile long and seventy yards wide, the water appearing to be about ten feet deep, although unusually low at the present time. A high range of hills exist to the north of this creek, and the watercourses all trend to the north-west; and, as our latitude is the same as the Reedy Brook of Leichhardt on the south-west side of the Valley of Lagoons, it is evident that these streams do not join the Burdekin, but are tributary to the Lynd, joining it probably at the southern bend.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteFirst: Torpor set in speedily, the buzz soon ceased, and the insects lay on their sides, motionless, but for occasional twitching of the legs. The wings, as a rule, became completely paralysed before the legs, and death occurred at a rather variable time, from
quoteLast: hours. If placed in a current of air in the sun, a fly completely under the influence of coniine may recover. Coniine causes in frogs, similar to curarine, peripheral paralysis of the motor nerves, combined with a transitory stimulation, and afterwards a paralysis of the motor centres; in frogs the paralysis is not preceded by convulsions.
title:
Poisons, Their Effects and Detection
A Manual for the Use of Analytical Chemists and Experts
